title: 109_hr5861
content: The Act titled "National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 2006" outlines the responsibilities of Historic Preservation Officers. The National Historic Preservation Act (16 U.S.C. 470a(b)) is amended to limit the authority of State Historic Preservation Officers in requiring identification of historic properties outside the project area. If there is no response within 30 days to a finding of 'no historic properties affected' or 'no adverse effect,' the Federal agency can proceed assuming no objections from the State or Tribal Preservation Officers. The Preservation Officer or Tribal Historic Preservation Officer has no objection to the finding. SEC. 3. ADDITIONAL CRITERIA FOR CERTIFICATION OF LOCAL GOVERNMENTS TO CARRY OUT NATIONAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION ACT. Section 101(c)(1) of the National Historic Preservation Act is amended to include a new subparagraph requiring entities to provide due process protection to property owners before using eligibility determinations for regulatory requirements. SEC. 4 amends the National Historic Preservation Act by changing the year from 2005 to 2015. SEC. 5 establishes an Advisory Council on Historic Preservation. The National Historic Preservation Act is amended to increase membership from four to seven, consolidate subsections (5) and (6) into paragraph (6), and increase the number of members in subsection (f) from nine to eleven. Financial and administrative services will be provided by the Department of the Interior or another agency chosen by the Council. The National Historic Preservation Act is amended to increase membership and financial/administrative services will be provided by the Department of the Interior or another chosen agency. Payments for services will be made in advance or reimbursed from Council funds as agreed upon by the Chairman and agency head. Federal agency regulations for collection of erroneous payments and administrative control of funds will apply. Authorization of appropriations is also included in the Act. Authorization of appropriations under the National Historic Preservation Act is amended to allow for necessary amounts to carry out the title, removing the previous limit of $4,000,000 per fiscal year from 1997 to 2005. The National Historic Preservation Act is amended to assess the effectiveness of federal grant and assistance programs. The Council may enter into cooperative agreements with Federal agencies to improve grant program administration. They can modify selection criteria and review program effectiveness to meet the Act's purposes. The Council can recommend improvements to federal grant programs to align with the Act's purposes and policies, as well as suggest appropriate funding levels to the President and Congress. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 25, 2006. Karen L. Haas attested to it as the Clerk.
